results.abstract: Growing number of space agencies around world are following lead of NASA, which promotes celebrity culture of telegenic astronauts and love of entertainment side of exploration; critics say this stifles more challenging work of sending humans and robotics probes to study distant worlds, but NASA has found winning formula for building political constituency to support its budget of $13.7 billion this year alone; photos (M)

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Heavenly Rewards; Shilling the Right Stuff

results.snippet: THE European Space Agency labored in obscurity for many years, achieving dozens of feats in the heavens that were ignored by most Europeans. Then, in 1983, Europe's first astronaut soared into space aboard a shuttle. Suddenly, millions of television...
results.lead_paragraph: THE European Space Agency labored in obscurity for many years, achieving dozens of feats in the heavens that were ignored by most Europeans. Then, in 1983, Europe's first astronaut soared into space aboard a shuttle. Suddenly, millions of television viewers across the continent were glued to their sets, watching a good-looking European explorer risk life and limb on the high frontier. Officials at the agency's headquarters in Paris were ecstatic. Eager for more, they quickly got the same religion as their counterparts in America, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which long ago had mastered the art of promoting space-age heroism. Belatedly, the Europeans discovered that public enthusiasm for sending people into space, a venture steeped in risk and danger, drama and the right stuff, was a sure way to win political support for space exploration and its great costs.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; The Littlest Astronaut

results.snippet: They may be the first septuagenarian action figures ever. As John Glenn prepared to be catapulted into space aboard the Discovery shuttle last week, miniature John Glenns began landing on toy-store shelves.    Courtesy of Mattel Inc. and its Hot...
results.lead_paragraph: They may be the first septuagenarian action figures ever. As John Glenn prepared to be catapulted into space aboard the Discovery shuttle last week, miniature John Glenns began landing on toy-store shelves. Courtesy of Mattel Inc. and its Hot Wheels label, children can now play with three tiny versions of the spacegoing Senator. There is John Glenn in the red space suit he is wearing on the Discovery, John Glenn in the silver space suit he wore when he became the first American to orbit the Earth in 1962 and, for those youngsters who get excited by filibustering and fund-raising, John Glenn the Senator, dressed in a navy blue suit and red tie.

results.abstract: Article nostalgia for space age among baby boomers, to whom space program promised not only real-life outer-space adventures but also hope of brave new world back home; photo (M)

headline.main: The Future Isn't What It Was

results.snippet: IT was a moment of national nostalgia. Cynicism was put on hold for the five minutes it took the spacecraft to vanish from our television screens. We prayed as we watched CNN last Thursday, remembering the last time so many took such interest in a...
results.lead_paragraph: IT was a moment of national nostalgia. Cynicism was put on hold for the five minutes it took the spacecraft to vanish from our television screens. We prayed as we watched CNN last Thursday, remembering the last time so many took such interest in a NASA launch. This one, thank heaven, seemed to work. If you remember John Glenn's historic 1962 Mercury flight -- or if, like me, you took Instamatic pictures of the television that day in 1969 when man first walked on the moon -- you felt like a kid again last week. That was when the astronaut-turned-senator-turned-astronaut returned to space aboard the shuttle Discovery at age 77. It was a feel-good media event.

results.abstract: Article on demise of urban newspaper columnist; focuses on Mike Royko, Jimmy Breslin and Herb Caen, who tied themselves to their cities' emotional geography, which they then reproduced through their distinctive writing styles; photos (M)

headline.main: Media; The urban newspaper column flourished when the city was king. Times have changed.

results.snippet: NEWSPAPER column about newspaper columnists is not simply a self-referential exercise. It is an almost inevitable act of reverence, done when a notable columnist dies or retires or even quits under fire. The death in 1997 of Mike Royko of The Chicago...
results.lead_paragraph: NEWSPAPER column about newspaper columnists is not simply a self-referential exercise. It is an almost inevitable act of reverence, done when a notable columnist dies or retires or even quits under fire. The death in 1997 of Mike Royko of The Chicago Tribune and the recent disgrace of Mike Barnicle of The Boston Globe -- who made his final farewell on The Globe's Op-Ed page last week -- created an almost Pavlovian response, sending journalists scurrying back to the collected works of New York's Damon Runyon or Baltimore's H. L. Mencken. The urge is to say that urban columnists aren't as important as they used to be. Clearly, the big names that resonate around the country are fewer. Those who mourn bygone days and columnists, however, are missing the point. What has changed is not so much the urban column but the way the city and the world have changed around it.

headline.main: Space Makes His Faith Stronger, Glenn Says

results.snippet: Senator John Glenn said today his return to space has strengthened his religious faith and illustrated the benefits of cooperating with other nations in space instead of competing with them, as was the case in his first flight three decades ago.   ...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator John Glenn said today his return to space has strengthened his religious faith and illustrated the benefits of cooperating with other nations in space instead of competing with them, as was the case in his first flight three decades ago. In his first news conference since Mr. Glenn and six crewmates went into orbit aboard the shuttle Discovery on Thursday, the 77-year-old astronaut-politician said he was healthy, sleeping well and keeping busy as both the subject of research and part-time scientist.

headline.main: Toronto's Newspaper War

results.snippet: When Conrad Black, one of the world's most powerful media barons, decided to start a national daily newspaper in Canada, he knew he had to do it in Toronto, the country's largest city and one of the most competitive newspaper markets in North...
results.lead_paragraph: When Conrad Black, one of the world's most powerful media barons, decided to start a national daily newspaper in Canada, he knew he had to do it in Toronto, the country's largest city and one of the most competitive newspaper markets in North America. But Toronto is already home to Canada's three largest English-language daily newspapers. Long before The National Post made its debut last Tuesday, the dailies had prepared for a newspaper war by fortifying their staffs and adding sections.

headline.main: 'Tonight' Host Trades Laughs With Shuttle

results.snippet: An astronaut young enough to be John Glenn's grandson stole the show from the veteran space traveler today in an interview from orbit with Jay Leno, the ''Tonight Show'' host.    Mr. Glenn, the 77-year-old veteran astronaut once described by former...
results.lead_paragraph: An astronaut young enough to be John Glenn's grandson stole the show from the veteran space traveler today in an interview from orbit with Jay Leno, the ''Tonight Show'' host. Mr. Glenn, the 77-year-old veteran astronaut once described by former President Jimmy Carter as the most boring man he had ever met, was unable to match the rapid-fire quips from Lieut. Col. Curtis L. Brown of the Air Force, 42, the commander of the space shuttle Discovery.

headline.main: New Faces In the Senate

results.snippet: ARKANSAS    Blanche Lambert Lincoln     Democrat, 38. Ms. Lincoln's defeat of Fay Boozman, a conservative Republican State Senator, keeps Democratic control of the seat held by Dale Bumpers, who is retiring. No stranger to Washington, Ms. Lincoln...
results.lead_paragraph: ARKANSAS Blanche Lambert Lincoln Democrat, 38. Ms. Lincoln's defeat of Fay Boozman, a conservative Republican State Senator, keeps Democratic control of the seat held by Dale Bumpers, who is retiring. No stranger to Washington, Ms. Lincoln was a lobbyist before beating Representative Bill Alexander, for whom she had worked as a receptionist, in 1992. A moderate, she did not seek re-election in 1996, mostly because she worried about campaigning in the heat of an Arkansas summer while she was pregnant with twins. While in Congress, she favored Federal money for abortion, the balanced-budget amendment and the North American Free Trade Agreement. She supports charter schools but says vouchers might dilute the resources of public schools.

headline.main: Astronaut's Adventure on Earth: Luge

results.snippet: When the space shuttle Discovery touches down tomorrow, the tallest astronaut, Scott Parazynski, a strapping, 6-foot-1-inch blond who looks like an actor and is a doctor, will have completed his third mission in space. But for all his achievements,...
results.lead_paragraph: When the space shuttle Discovery touches down tomorrow, the tallest astronaut, Scott Parazynski, a strapping, 6-foot-1-inch blond who looks like an actor and is a doctor, will have completed his third mission in space. But for all his achievements, Parazynski will land with his greatest dream still unfulfilled: to be a United States Olympic luger. Those who have followed John Glenn's latest space odyssey have heard of Parazynski, the mission specialist and the doctor responsible for drawing most of Glenn's blood samples during Discovery's nine-day orbit of Earth.

Inspections of Iraq The Clinton Administration is preparing to abandon the United Nations inspections regime in Iraq, senior American officials said. The Administration is choosing other forms of traditional containment, including continued sanctions and the use of force, which now seems more likely than at any time since the gulf war ended in 1991, the officials say. 1

headline.main: Glenn Back on Ground, Head Still Above Clouds

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery returned safely to the Kennedy Space Center today after a nine-day mission with the world's oldest astronaut, Senator John Glenn, who reassured Mission Control that he felt as good on Earth as he had in space.    ''I'm...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery returned safely to the Kennedy Space Center today after a nine-day mission with the world's oldest astronaut, Senator John Glenn, who reassured Mission Control that he felt as good on Earth as he had in space. ''I'm going to reprise a statement that I made a long, long time ago,'' the 77-year-old Mr. Glenn said on landing, ''except this time it is, 'One-G and I feel fine.' Discovery and this crew took us around and around, and that view is still tremendous.''

results.abstract: John Glenn says he slept 'like a log' his first night back on Earth after nine-day shuttle mission; says he 'didn't feel too hot' when he emerged from Discovery shuttle upon landing; NASA doctors say none of astronauts show significant medical problems; photo (M)

headline.main: After a Sound Sleep, Glenn Says He Feels Fine

results.snippet: John Glenn, the world's oldest space traveler, said today that he slept ''like a log'' his first night back on Earth after a nine-day shuttle mission.    At the Discovery crew's first news conference after their return, Senator Glenn admitted that he...
results.lead_paragraph: John Glenn, the world's oldest space traveler, said today that he slept ''like a log'' his first night back on Earth after a nine-day shuttle mission. At the Discovery crew's first news conference after their return, Senator Glenn admitted that he ''didn't feel too hot'' when he emerged from the shuttle upon landing on Saturday. Mr. Glenn, 77, who in 1962 became the first American to orbit Earth, said he struggled against gravity.

headline.main: Glenn to Touch Down for a Parade

results.snippet: Now that he's the world's oldest astronaut, what on Earth will John Glenn do?    This morning, Mr. Glenn, 77, is to unveil a 12-foot star atop the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center. Then he and his fellow crew members from the space shuttle...
results.lead_paragraph: Now that he's the world's oldest astronaut, what on Earth will John Glenn do? This morning, Mr. Glenn, 77, is to unveil a 12-foot star atop the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center. Then he and his fellow crew members from the space shuttle Discovery are to join Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for breakfast at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline.main: In Line of Parades, One for Glenn and the Crew of Discovery

results.snippet: With golden sunlight glazing the autumn leaves and a light breeze sweeping down Broadway, it seemed a great day to honor John Glenn, and for tens of thousands of people, it was.    But for the longest time yesterday morning, almost the only people to...
results.lead_paragraph: With golden sunlight glazing the autumn leaves and a light breeze sweeping down Broadway, it seemed a great day to honor John Glenn, and for tens of thousands of people, it was. But for the longest time yesterday morning, almost the only people to show up to honor the 77-year-old astronaut, United States Senator and undisputed American hero were the police, firefighters and sanitation workers assigned to handle the crowd. And even once the parade got under way, crowds were -- by New York standards -- modest if not thin, with indications along the traditional parade route that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani might have overestimated the public's appetite for a third ticker tape extravaganza since October.

headline.main: About New York; Once Makers, Now Students Of History

results.snippet: JOHN GLENN proved that a 77-year-old politician and former astronaut could pull a few levers of power and once again explore the final frontier. He returned to Earth and New York, where the modest flurry of ticker tape could have been outdone had...
results.lead_paragraph: JOHN GLENN proved that a 77-year-old politician and former astronaut could pull a few levers of power and once again explore the final frontier. He returned to Earth and New York, where the modest flurry of ticker tape could have been outdone had people showered him with shredded copies of the articles about how his trip was a victory for the elderly. Gina Liebow would now like to have the final two words on all this.

results.abstract: Article on mental illness that plagued Margaret Mary Ray, stalker of David Letterman who committed suicide, and her family; says Ray, one of four siblings, was third to become ill and third to commit suicide; photos (M)

headline.main: Behind the Jokes, a Life Of Pain and Delusion; For Letterman Stalker, Mental Illness Was Family Curse and Scarring Legacy

results.snippet: Although she spent much of her time in the thrall of delusions, Margaret Mary Ray wrote her last missive to her mother in what seemed to be a moment of clarity.    She mentioned her love for her children, wrested so many years earlier from her care....
results.lead_paragraph: Although she spent much of her time in the thrall of delusions, Margaret Mary Ray wrote her last missive to her mother in what seemed to be a moment of clarity. She mentioned her love for her children, wrested so many years earlier from her care. She said she had tried, in her way, to be good to them. And she gave vent to her exhaustion and disillusionment, hinting that she understood how untenable her existence had become. ''I'm all traveled out,'' Ms. Ray, 46, said in the letter, which was written before her death on Oct. 5, but reached her mother, Loretta Duvall in Greenwich, Conn., when it was too late. ''I chose a painless and instantaneous way to end my life in the valley I loved.''

results.abstract: Jesse Ventura transformation from wrestler to radio host to Governor-elect of Minnesota is mirrored less dramatically across the country, where millions of people have invented new careers for themselves, driven either by necessity or some inner longing; drawing (M)

headline.main: The World: Second Acts, and Beyond; Check Out the 'Me, Reborn' Generation

results.snippet: LOOKING for a role model for your career? How about Jesse Ventura, the menacing wrestler turned blustery radio host turned straight-talking Minnesota Governor-elect?    The election of Mr. Ventura this month may have seemed simply a golden moment in...
results.lead_paragraph: LOOKING for a role model for your career? How about Jesse Ventura, the menacing wrestler turned blustery radio host turned straight-talking Minnesota Governor-elect? The election of Mr. Ventura this month may have seemed simply a golden moment in political eccentricity. But if you wade through the bulging bookshelf of tomes on the changing nature of careers in America, Mr. Ventura looks like something else as well -- a poster boy for the new post-downsizing, information-age ethos of creative reinvention that various deep thinkers trumpet as the new norm in the American workplace.

results.abstract: Special report, A Good Last Place, on Providence-Mount St Vincent nursing home in Seattle; Mount, as those who live there call it, is widely regarded to be what many Americans consider impossibility: good nursing home; it has found ways to be home to people who can no longer care for themselves and to be community that is more about living than about dying; nursing home's population of 215 men and women is similar to that of most nursing homes; average age of residents is 88; eighty percent suffer from some degree of dementia; aides, nurses and social workers keep residents clean and fed and treat them with respect and dignity; with nearly half of all Americans who reach 65 expected to spend time in nursing home, health care professionals are looking to Mount and handful of places like it for answers; photos (L)

headline.main: A GOOD LAST PLACE -- A special report; Seattle's Elderly Find a Home for Living, Not Dying

results.lead_paragraph: It was Saturday night at the Providence-Mount St. Vincent nursing home. Marie Swegle, 96, and her friends on the fifth floor were lingering at the dinner table in their wheelchairs, watching the news. John Glenn had safely returned to Earth. Mrs. Swegle, who a year before had learned to walk again after falling and breaking her neck, was not overly impressed by the 77-year-old astronaut. Neither was Effie Constantine, at 67 a good 15 years younger than anyone else at the table but crippled by hydrocephalus. ''It's a waste of money, sending him up in space,'' she said. ''Why don't they spend the money to study aging on earth?''

headline.main: Sports of the Times; Outfielder, Then College Valedictorian

results.snippet: HE was known as Tito Landrum back in the 80's. He stood in against Nolan Ryan and Doc Gooden when their fastballs buzzed under his chin, but he never knew fear until he sat in a classroom at New York University.    ''Those kids were more qualified...
results.lead_paragraph: HE was known as Tito Landrum back in the 80's. He stood in against Nolan Ryan and Doc Gooden when their fastballs buzzed under his chin, but he never knew fear until he sat in a classroom at New York University. ''Those kids were more qualified than me,'' he said the other day, a college graduate, a man with a future. ''There would be a three-hour class and a half-hour break and another three-hour class. I did not know how to handle it. I was out of the loop.''
